title: My problem with the support class
body:
So I had a thought and felt it would be better to express it in a thread.  I'm sure this thought has come up several times before however.

I feel supports aren't really supports.  They feel more like guardians for the ADC.  Everything the support offers seems to benefit the ADC more than anyone else on their team.  Shields, AS, healing, all benefit the guy who has a low health pool and heavily relies on basic stats and kiting to function (course I'm biased here).  These things could be beneficial to other roles, but they don't need them because they need to be somewhat self-sufficient.  Fighters and tanks have healing or defensive steroids of their own, mages don't bring out enough DPS and are usually much more ranged in a fight so they don't need the constant protection.

When I play support, 90% of my thought process in a teamfight seems to be "keep the ADC alive" because I know that will win us the fight more or less.  No other class is better suited for my buffs and peel, and therefore the ADC takes priority.  It's weird because if a team actually helped a heavily stacked Nasus reach his targets, then he'd be very useful.

IDK, I think that supports need to be more team helpful then ADC sitters.

replies.body:
A good support already knows to prioritize the carry in team fights... and that's not always your bottom marksman.

If I have a 9/1 Nasus obliterating enemies left and right as long as he can get to them in the same game as an adc that isn't making an impact, you can bet your ass that I'll be focusing on helping Nasus carry the team to victory.

A good support isn't an adc-sitter. You just start out that way at level 1. The rest is up to you.

Support and jungle are (imo) the most impactful roles because it's primarily up to them to have the best understanding of the overall match and make the kind of choices other players don't have to make. Who do you get ahead? Where do you set up the big plays? etc etc

It's not a fault in the class design. This is just another choice you have to make.
Support don't do a whole lot hence why it's autofill and why it's always the least desired role by a long shot

No, it's the least understood role. Support is actually a super versatile carry role for people who know what they're doing.

Supports are constantly keeping track of vision, enemy jgl rotations, how each laner is doing, when they should/shouldn't roam, when the best time for drag/rift herald are doing, making sure they get their adc fed early/establish a safe farming lane for them etc etc. And if a support isn't doing all that, then they aren't doing it right.

I've been playing support for years and it's mainly for two reasons:

- 1) If I'm not doing it, it's probably being done wrong
- 2) I get bored in other roles bc the only other role that has as big of an impact on a game is jungle
It's the easiest role because you don't do a whole lot.

Maybe you should play support then. You could easily climb out of silver with it.

Joking aside, have you ever actually WATCHED high tier support play? The micro you need to do is insane. A good support is usually actually UNDERLEVELED because they spend so much time doing the jobs that don't get recognized.
Umm I pick fill and pretty much only get supp because no one wants to play it shocking . Neither do I so I just play skarner supp because it works and I can tolerate it
You're rocking a 38% win rate on support. If it's a role where you don't do a whole lot, how is it that you manage to make your team lose?

Isn't the support's job more macro than micro generally?  Not saying it's easy, just in a different section.

Maybe I'm just misunderstanding macro vs micro here.

Ehhh that depends. With all of the active items you should be using, plus your warding, sweeping, all of that: I tend to quantify that as more micro than macro. Macro is just general map and game knowledge imo.

I kind of think of macro as rotating for objectives, forcing team fights, setting up pushing waves - micro is more like individual ability usage, where and when you ward, dodging abilities, etc.
I just see warding as much more macro seeing as how it's all about map control.

I think the action of USING and defending map control is macro; but the wards themselves, the vision you can get by placing it perfectly, the timing of being able to slip away in lane to plant on in a great spot: all of that just screams micro to me.

As a better clarification, I use two different ideas on the two. 

Your macro play is what you do as a team. Moving as a unit to place wards I would consider macro as it involves a concentrated team effort. A solid split push plan is macro in a 1/3/1 with baron. HOWEVER, your respective 1v1s in the side lanes, and your individual defensive wards you use for protection are micro as it is relevant to you as an individual to use the tools you have most effectively.

You can kind of think about it in the sense of micro is your ability to do a play that solo carries, and macro is what you use to get your team to win.

If not picked botside it would encourage duo toplane and safer ranged picks bot, or picks that can tolerate a duo lane.

Meanwhile you still shield the ADC because it gives AD, unless someone else is literally one hit from dying and the ADC isn't attacking anyone
